response.answer_text: Snobs rarely like the hoi polloi — that is, the masses, a.k.a. "the great unwashed." The term comes from the Greek for "the many." Perhaps because of the similar sounding term hoity-toity to mean someone with fancy airs the phrase is sometimes mistaken for its exact opposite — the elite or upper class. Hi, I believe this term came from the English when their empire spanned the world and was similar in meaning as politicians use today when they refer to ‘mums and dads’. It is a demeaning term that refers to people who did not have bathing and washing facilities because they were poor. The term was used extensively by the British to describe the native of a country they occupied, especially in India. Japanese used the term, ‘unclean,’ as did several religions referring to non-believers. But, that specific tern first came out as a pejorative appellation was used by a Victorian novelist and playwright Edward Bulwer-Lyttonin in his 1830 novel Paul Clifford. The Great Unwashed was a derogatory remark made against the ordinary, poor, common man around 18–19th century. Supposedly reflecting their unhygienic and unwashed personas. 20–21st century we apply it to the “Posh”, upper class, or well to do, rich people who also had the phrased coined for them “Too posh to wash” because they never do anything to get dirty(?). We could also recall 17–18th century where King Louis the XIV of France set an example by only ever having 2 baths in his life time.
